Locus.desc: The physical result of any single action whether it leaves a positive or negative record within the stratigraphic sequence. (MoLAS 1994)

cols.Locus_Locus_ID:
Locus ID Every archaeological locus (negative element (cut), deposit, structure, skeleton, artefact cluster) is given a unique 3 or 4 letter locus code. Each trench is designated with a separate letter which starts the code, so it is immediately obvious to which trench a locus belongs. For example locus HAA belongs to Trench H, locus MQP to Trench M etc. The loci are labelled consecutively in alphabetical order using the letters following the trench letter. For Trench H the first locus would be HAA, the second HAB, the third HAB and so on. In addition sets of letters can denote parts of trenches, buildings etc. E.g. HFs might denote loci from a specific building. Burial locus codes begin with the letter Z, followed by the trench letter. Hence burial ZHA is the first burial locus from trench H. Check with the trench supervisor who will assign the locus code from the central register.

Basal_Edge_Definition.desc: Describe the boundary between this and the next locus.

opts.opt: DoubtfulYou are uncertain of whether you accurately excavated a boundary between deposits
AmbiguousYou are uncertain as to whether there was a boundary between loci.
MergingThere is a distinction between the excavated locus and earlier locus/loci but the excavated loci and the earlier loci grade into each other
ClearThe boundary with the earlier locus/loci was very clearly defined during excavation.
ArbitrarySpitThere is no meaningful boundary with an earlier locus. The boundary has been artificially created by the excavation process.

Contamination.desc: The extent to which the locus has been contaminated.

Locus_Type.desc: Describe the locus type by selecting an icon as defined below. When you have selected a locus type you can proceed to open the "Fill in locus type details" page. Note this page will not open unless you have selected a locus type.

opts.opt: Cut Any Locus which represents the removal of earlier deposit and thus forms a negative interface (cut) with another locus, such as a cut for a pit, burial, ditch, wall foundation or robber trench.
Deposit Any Locus with deposited sediment and soil, such as floor layers, pit and grave fills, hearth fills and natural sediments.
Natural Any Locus with deposited sediment and soil, such as floor layers, pit and grave fills, hearth fills and natural sediments.
Construction Any Locus consisting of deliberately constructed structural element, independent of a Negative Element (i.e. cut, such as a wall or a hearth).

Date_Closed.desc: The date excavation of the Locus ended and it was closed. Press the 'Add Date Closed' button to insert today's date.

cols.Measure_Depth: Depth (m) Depth or Height in metres.

Measure.Volume_Liters: Volume (liters) Estimate the volume of the locus in liters. All soil will be collected in buckets of a known volume. A tally should be kept of buckets produced from a locus and the total volume calculated using that tally.

Cut.Cut_Your_Interpretation:

No Observation Hangtu Indeterminate Animal/Plant hole Stakehole Posthole Pit Hearth/Fire pit Ditch/Trench Construction Cut Burial Erosional Feature Other Function not elsewhere described. Provide details in Annotation field.

opts.opt: Gradual Some rounding to the top.

Sharp Clear sharp slope, almost right-angled.
Shallow Gentle slope less than 45 degrees.

opts.opt: Gradual Some rounding to the top.

Deposit.Deposit_Your_Interpretation:
Your Interpretation Your interpretation of the likely function of the locus.
No Observation Hangtu Indeterminate You are unable to make an assessment of possible function. Packing Packing in a post hole for post material fulfilling a constructional purpose other than deliberate levelling deposits. Makeup/Levelling Material laid down to level or raise an area for constructional purposes or other activities. Dump Material probably dumped as a result of other activity e.g. material removed from cuts or other constructional or destructional activity. Midden Distinct area of organic rubbish accumulation Burial A fill or other deposit associated with a skeleton and forming part of a burial feature. Structural Debris/Collapse Material derived from collapse of a wall, roof or other structure Partly naturally derived A deposit partly or wholly accumulating through natural sedimentary processes, such as water or wind deposition. Wholly naturally derived All of the deposit accumulating through the deposition of natural sediments through geomorphological processes eg wind borne sediments water-laid natural sediments material flaking from cave and rock shelter walls. Erosional products Material deriving from the erosion of earlier archaeological sediments. Artifact Cluster A distinct concentration of artifacts or ecofacts. Make sure you record its xyz coordinates centre and edges. Ash/Charcoal A deposit consisting largely of carbonized/charred plant material and/or ash Arbitrary This applies to artificial loci excavated for excavational convenience eg section cleaning material whose precise provenience is unclear. Does not include arbitrary spits or spatial units deliberately excavated for finer control of horizontal and vert Distinct floor contact To be used for material that directly reflects the use of a surface or floor - artefact material on the surface perhaps thin deposits of occupation material. These loci will be gridded into spatial units for closer control of artifact distributions. Animal/Plant Deposit derived from plant or animal activity Other Function not elsewhere described. Provide details in Annotation field.

Texture.desc: Describe the compaction of the sediments in the Locus.

opts.opt: Medium Compact Somewhere between loose and compact.
Concrete Rock hard resistant to trowelling.
Friable Deposit disintegrates into small particles under pressure.
Crumbly Deposit disintegrates into lumps under pressure.

Texture_Description.desc: Description of the compaction of soil including changes throughout the deposit. Eg "Varies from loose to compact."

Soil_Particle_Sorting.desc: Assessment of the frequency with which particles of the same size occur.

opts.opt: Moderately sorted Particles are mostly the same size and evenly distributed but there are some larger particles.
Poorly sorted Particles are different sizes and unevenly distributed.
Very poorly sorted Particles are very different sizes and very unevenly distributed.
Well sorted Particles are roughly the same size and evenly distributed.

Material.desc: The type of sediment, eg clay, silt, sand and loam. Use the Material Helper or a Soil Sediment diagram for assisance.

opts.opt: No Observation No Observation. Use the Texture helper to prefil this.
Sand A sand has a loose gritty feel and does not stick together. Individual sand grains can be seen or felt. (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)
Loamy Sand In a loamy sand particles barely stick together and a moulded piece of soil just holds its shape. (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)
Silty Clay Loam A silty clay loam is like a clay loam but silty as well and smooth to the touch. (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)

Clay Loam More easily moulded into a shape than a loam a clay loam rolls out to a thin ribbon between the palms while a loam will break-up. When dry a clay loam will form a lump but is not as tough to break as a clay.(VDEPI 2009: AG0058)
Sandy Clay Loam A sandy clay loam is like a clay loam but sand grains can be felt (and heard - see Sandy Loam) (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)

Silt Loam A silty loam is like a loam but has a smooth silky feel when a moist sample is pushed between the index finger and thumb. On drying a sample can form a hard lump but this may be broken by hand. (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)

Loam A loam breaks into crumbs but will tend to stick together. Sand grains cannot be felt in a moist sample which when squeezed will retain its shape when handled freely. Loams are usually soft to the feel. (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)

Sandy Loam A sandy loam sticks together more than a loamy sand but can be easily broken. Individual sand grains can be felt and heard if a wet sample is rubbed between the index finger and thumb and held close to the ear. (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)
Silty Clay A silty clay is like a clay but smoother. (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)

Clay Clays are tough and can be moulded into shapes when moist. Clays form a long flexible ribbon when rubbed between the palms and the ribbon can often be bent into a U shape without breaking. Clays dry into very hard clods. (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)
Sandy Clay A sandy clay is like a clay but sand grains can be felt (and heard - see Sandy Loam). (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)

Skeleton.Skeleton_Dimensions: Dimensions Record the approximate extent of the skeletal remains (in meters or millimetres only) and the axis of measurement. Detailed dimensions can be taken from the plan.

cols.Skeleton_Head: Head Which way up the head faces and/or points
cols.Skeleton_Body: Body Describe the attitude of the body, whether it is extended, crouched, flexed, supine (front up), prone (face down) and the orientation.

cols.Skeleton_Left_Arm: Left Arm and Hand Location Record whether left arm is straight or flexed, is along the side of the body, over the chest or on the pelvis, and the position of the hand.
cols.Skeleton_Right_Arm: Right Arm and Hand Location Record whether right arm is straight or flexed, is along the side of the body, over the chest or on the pelvis, and the position of the hand.

cols.Skeleton_Left_Leg: Left Leg and Foot Location Record whether the leg is straight or bent, crossed left over right or right over left and the position of the foot
cols.Skeleton_Right_Leg: Right Leg and Foot Location Record whether the leg is straight or bent, crossed left over right or right over left and the position of the foot

Skeleton.Skeleton_Condition: Condition Describe the general condition of the skeleton and any comments on articulation. Any degeneration of bone in situ is important to record as well as accidental damage during excavation and lifting. Record disturbances through later activity or animal/root activity as well as damage due to stone pressure on the bones. It is important to note whether the patellae, hyoid, phalanges, basi-occipital etc are present or not, and their location, as this may give an indication of the state of the body at the time of interment.
Skeleton.Skeleton_Surface_Modifications: Surface Modifications Note any cut marks, evidence of stains and/or colour during the course of the excavation, burning, chewing marks, root activity etc.
Skeleton.Skeleton_Environment: Condition and Weather The physical environment at the time of excavation may affect the state of the bone therefore it is important to note the weather and conditions you are working in.
Skeleton.Skeleton_Days_Exposed: Number of Days Exposed It is important to excavate skeletal remains as quickly as possible as the state of the bone will change during exposure. Any conditional change should also be noted. Excavate as quickly as possible because the bones will degrade rapidly.
